docs.title: TeXSmith Exam Template
docs.text:
This project provides an exam template for TeXSmith. It includes an exam-centric LATEX renderer with callouts and a structure tailored for assessments.

The template is currently tailored for HEIG-VD. The long-term goal is to offer a more generic version with configurable branding (logos, color palettes, and similar options).

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Add the template as a dependency and install the required dependency groups:

uv sync --group dev --group docs

docs.title: Quick start
docs.text:
Use the exam template with TeXSmith:

texsmith render --template exam exam.md

Enable solution mode when rendering to build the answer key:

texsmith render --template exam -a solution=true exam.md

docs.title: Title page
docs.text:
By default the template generates a dedicated cover page with the duration, grade table, and rules. To render a minimal inline title instead, set exam.titlepage to minimal in the front matter:

exam:
  titlepage: minimal

docs.title: Template syntax
docs.text: This template extends TeXSmith with a few exam-specific Markdown helpers.

docs.title: Headings
docs.text:
Because exams are structured as questions and parts, the usual Markdown headings map to question, part, and subpart entries in the LATEX output. In Markdown, you just use headings as usual. Example:

# Exam Title

## Question 1

### Part 1.1

#### Subpart 1.1.1

### Part 1.2

## Question 2

Often you need a part or subpart with no visible title. Use - as the heading text to keep the structure while hiding the title:

## Question

### -

Text for part 1

### -

Text for part 2

#### -

Text for subpart 1 of part 2

Info

The - label resembles a list marker and keeps Markdown headings non-empty, so they still parse correctly.

If you need plain LATEX sectioning (instead of exam questions/parts), mark a heading with {heading=true}. The marked heading and its subheadings are rendered with TeXSmith's standard \section, \subsection, etc.

## Context {heading=true}

### Model

### Variables

docs.title: Multiple choice
docs.text:
Markdown (and TeXSmith) supports task lists like - [ ]. With this template, task list items are rendered as multiple-choice answers.

## Volcanoes

Which volcanoes are located in Italy? (multiple answers)

- [x] Etna
- [ ] Krakatoa
- [x] Vesuvius
- [ ] Mauna Loa
- [ ] Fuji
- [x] Stromboli
- [ ] Kilauea

Checked entries are treated as correct answers. They appear only in the answer key, not on the student copy.

You do not need to manage layout manually: the columen LATEX package arranges answers into columns based on available space.

docs.title: Fill-in blanks
docs.text:
Inline fill-ins turn into exam-style answer blanks:

The capital of Switzerland is [Bern]{w=30}.

The optional attribute block lets you specify the blank width. By default, the width is computed from the answer text. If you want to avoid revealing the expected length, set an explicit width (w=1cm, w=1in, or similar). Both width and w are accepted.

In the front matter you can configure exam.char-width-scale to scale the automatic width when no explicit size is provided.

docs.title: Solution blocks
docs.text:
Use admonitions to provide solutions and mark answers.

!!! solution

    Solution content appears only in the answer key

For short answers, you can request lined space. In the answer key the lines are replaced by the solution text.

!!! solution { lines=3 }

    Solution text...

Sometimes you need a grid instead of dotted lines.

## -

Draw an equilateral triangle

!!! solution { grid=3cm }

    ![Triangle]{triangle.svg}

Or you can reserve an empty box for drawings or other free-form answers.

## -

Draw a sheep:

!!! solution { box=5cm }

    Here is an example of the expected drawing:

    ![Sheep]{sheep.svg}

    The result should resemble a sheep with wool and four legs.
